qas.question: How do the meteorites found in Antarctica add to knowledge about the solar system?
Beside rare types of meteorites, what other types of meteorites have been found in Antarctica?
From where in the solar system could the meteorites have come?
About what nearby planet could the Antarctic meteorites hold data?
What do meteorites absorb that can be used to understand how old the meteorite is?

plausible_answers.text: possible evidence of microbial life on Mars.

context: This large collection of meteorites allows a <a0_0>better understanding<a0_0/> of the abundance of meteorite types in the solar system and how meteorites relate to asteroids and comets. <a1_0>New types<a1_0/> of <b5_0>meteorites<b5_0/> and rare meteorites have been found. Among these are pieces blasted off the <a2_0>Moon<a2_0/>, and probably Mars, by impacts. These specimens, particularly ALH84001 discovered by <b6_0>ANSMET<b6_0/>, are at the center of the controversy about <b7_0>possible evidence of microbial life on <a3_0>Mars<a3_0/>.<b7_0/> Because meteorites in space absorb and record <a4_0>cosmic radiation<a4_0/>, the time elapsed since the meteorite hit the Earth can be determined from laboratory studies. The elapsed time since fall, or terrestrial residence age, of a meteorite represents more information that might be useful in environmental studies of Antarctic ice sheets.
